In this work, effect of alumina surface chemistry on physicochemical properties and isobutane dehydrogenation activity of CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts with ca. 13 wt. % Cr was investigated. For this purpose, three catalysts were synthesized from η-Al2O3 samples which have identical textural properties but different density of Lewis acid sites (LAS) and OH groups as revealed by IR spectroscopy of adsorbed CO and pyridine. Systematic investigation of CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts with a number of techniques (chemical analysis, N2 adsorption, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy) showed that (a) Cr6+ and Cr3+ quantities as well as surface areas are the same; (b) quantity of low-active large α-Cr2O3 (> ca. 5 nm) and very small CrOx species (< ca. 1 nm) diminishes while (c) content of partially crystallized Cr2O3 particles from ca. 1 to about 5 nm size increases with the LAS density on parent η-Al2O3 and its dehydroxylation. Correspondingly, isobutane dehydrogenation activity at low times on stream (up to 40 min at 570 °C) increases. This activity difference was observed in the course of 50 dehydrogenation-regeneration cycles. Therefore, alumina surface chemistry strongly affects the Cr2O3 dispersion and dehydrogenation performance of high-loaded chromia/alumina catalysts. On the basis of the results, a model of surface structure for CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts was proposed including surface migration of chromium being dependent upon LAS and OH groups of Al2O3. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts Dehydrogenation Alumina Lewis acid sites OH groups 1 Introduction Light alkenes C3-C4 are among the most valuable intermediate products in the chemical industry. Propene, isobutene and butadiene-1,3 are used for fabrication of wide range of substances like different polymers, oxygenates, etc. [1–4]. Steam cracking and fluid catalytic cracking are the main industrial routes for production of C3-C4 alkenes. However, C3-C4 alkene selectivity in these processes is low, and highly selective on-purpose technologies such as C3-C4 alkane catalytic dehydrogenation are paid much attention. Nowadays supported CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts are used in several dehydrogenation processes (Catofin and Catadiene by CB&I Lummus, FBD by Snamprogetti-Yarsintez) [1,2,4,5]. Therefore, a lot of efforts have been made over the last several decades to elucidate structure-activity relationship of supported CrOx-based systems. Many investigations have been devoted to issues concerning nature of active sites [6–10], structure sensitivity [11–14], dehydrogenation kinetics [15–17], role of support on structure of CrOx species [7,18–20], metal doping effects [5,21–23], etc. Specifically, influence of support on Cr-speciation and catalytic activity has been studied principally by changing the chemical composition of support (Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2, TiO2, Al2O3-SiO2, etc. [7,18–20]). At the same time, little is known about the role of alumina properties on the characteristics of CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts. In the previous work of some of the present authors, the effect of alumina polymorph (γ-, η-, δ-, δ/θ- and θ-Al2O3) was studied on the dehydrogenation activity of chromia/alumina catalysts with about 3-6 wt.% of Cr (ca. 4.4 at. Cr/nm2) [24]. It was observed that dehydrogenation performance is highly dependent upon alumina type. Dehydrogenation activity and stability were strongly enhanced by using alumina polymorphs with increased surface density of Lewis acid sites which affect Cr3+Ox clustering [24]. A question arises if there would be the effect of alumina surface chemistry on characteristics of CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts with about 12–14 wt.% of Cr (10–30 at. Cr/nm2) which are typically used in industry [15–17,25–27]. The object of this work is to study the influence of alumina functional groups on physicochemical and catalytic properties of chromia/alumina catalysts with ca. 13 wt.% Cr (ca. 15 at. Cr/nm2). For this purpose, three catalysts were prepared with the use of three aluminas which have very similar textural properties but different amounts of Lewis acid sites (LAS) and OH groups. η-Al2O3 polymorph which is atypical for chromia/alumina catalysts was used as support. The reason for using η-Al2O3 samples rather than conventional γ-Al2O3 is twofold. First, CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts usually have higher dehydrogenation activity as compared to CrOx/γ-Al2O3 counterparts with similar Cr surface density (at. Cr/nm2) [24,28,29]. Secondly, CrOx/η-Al2O3 dehydrogenation catalysts are more stable against irreversible deactivation in the course of industrial exploitation [28,30,31]. On the basis of the results observed, a new model for surface structure of chromia/alumina catalysts was proposed which was based on the structure-descriptive role of LAS and OH groups of alumina. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the samples 2.1.1 Alumina supports Bayerite Al(OH)3 (Pural BT, Sasol) was used as precursor for η-Al2O3 supports. Al(OH)3 was shaped by extrusion after kneading in a laboratory mixer with an aqueous solution of nitric acid (extra high purity grade, Reachim, Russia) with subsequent drying at 120 °C. Three calcination procedures were applied to produce three η-Al2O3 samples with identical textural characteristics. First support was made by calcining the hydroxide at 800 °C for 4 h in air. Other two supports were prepared in a two-staged calcination procedure. At first, granulated bayerite was decomposed into Al2O3 at 600 °C in air for 1 h to withdraw the structural water and eliminate NOx-species. At the second stage, the resulting Al2O3 was calcined in air-steam atmosphere which is known to strongly enhance alumina sintering [32,33]. One sintering regime was conducted at 600 °C in mixture air: steam = 1: 4 for 2 h. The second sintering was performed at 700 °C in mixture air: steam = 4: 1 for 1 h. Air-steam mixtures were made by passing air and distilled water through the Controlled Evaporator Mixer (Bronkhorst). Cooling the steamed support was conducted in air. Thus obtained aluminas were labeled as η-Al2O3-T, were T is the temperature of the last stage of calcination. γ-Al2O3 reference sample was prepared from Trilobe Alumina Type II (Sasol, product no. Z600200) by calcining at 800 °C for 4 h in air. X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the resulting support is γ-Al2O3 with signs of δ-Al2O3 formation (Fig. 1 S). 2.1.2 Catalysts CrOx/Al2O3 Catalysts preparation was accomplished by incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method. Three η-Al2O3 samples were crushed and sieved to a fraction of 0.1–0.5 mm before the impregnation to ensure homogeneous Cr distribution across the catalyst particles [34]. A 6.2 M aqueous solution of CrO3 (>99.0%, Russia) was used for impregnation. The concentration was chosen so that the resulting Cr content in the catalysts was about 13 wt. %. Thus, Cr content conforms the composition of industrial CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts [15–17,25,26,35]. Wet catalysts were dried at 120 °C and subsequently calcined at 750 °C in air for 2 h. The catalysts are referred to as CrOx/N, where N is support designation. For comparison purposes, an laboratory analogue of industrial K-CrOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was synthesized according to the procedure described in a patent of Süd-Chemie [35]. Impregnation solution prepared by dissolving the KOH (≥85%, Russia) and CrO3 in distilled water was used for IWI of γ-Al2O3 reference sample (0.25–0.5 mm fraction). The catalyst precursor was dried at 120 °C and calcined at 760 °C in air for 4 h [35]. BET surface area for the resulting catalyst was 112 m2/g. Concentrations of the constituents were 13.0 wt.% Cr and 0.54 wt.% K according to potentiometric titration data (Section 2.2) and inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), respectively. 2.2 Physicochemical properties of supports and catalysts The total Cr and Cr6+ content in the catalysts was determined by potentiometric titration of Cr6+ with ferrous ammonium sulfate after sample preparation as follows. Catalyst samples were dissolved in the hot sulfuric acid solution with (for the total Cr) and without (for Cr6+) subsequent oxidation by an excess of ammonium persulfate using silver nitrate as catalyst. The excess of the oxidant was decomposed by boiling the solution. Experimental error of technique is lower than 5% of the average value. The Cr/Cr6+ values presented are averaged data of three measurements. The CHNS analysis of the coked catalysts was performed using Euro ЕА3000 analyzer. Measurements of N2 adsorption at the liquid nitrogen temperature were performed after degassing the samples in vacuum at 150 °C with ASAP 2400 instrument (Micromeritics). The surface area (SBET) was calculated using the BET equation from selected N2 adsorption data within the range of relative pressure from 0.05 to 0.2.The pore diameter (Dpore) was evaluated with the BJH method using desorption branch of the isotherm. The total pore volume (Vpore) was estimated by converting the amount of N2 gas adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.99 to volume of liquid N2. Uncertainty of the obtained results is 5%. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 0.15418 nm) equipped with a LynxEye position-sensitive detector. Measurements were performed in the 2θ range of 14°–71° with a step of 0.05° and a collection time of 3 s. The average sizes of the coherently scattering domain (CSD) DXRD were calculated by the line broadening analysis according to the Scherrer equation. The ICDD PDF-2 database (Powder Diffraction File database PDF-2, International Center for Diffraction Data, USA, 2009) was used for phase identification. Properties of alumina surfaces were characterized by FTIR spectroscopy using adsorption of carbon monoxide. The powder samples were pressed into pellets of 1 × 2 cm2 and 35–45 mg in mass. The pellets were activated in a special IR cell at 500 °C for 2 h in vacuum of 10−4 Torr. IR spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu IRTracer-100 spectrometer within the spectral range of 400–6000 cm−1 using 200 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The adsorption of CO was performed at −196 °C from 0.1 to 10 Torr of CO pressure. The spectra in the absorption scale were normalized to the optical thickness (g/cm2) of pellets. The corresponding IR bands were deconvoluted into the individual Gauss components. The concentrations of various acid sites were determined from the integral intensities (S) of characteristic absorption bands using the integral coefficients of absorption (k) by Eq. (1). (1) C = S k The integral coefficients of absorption was 0.9, 1.1 and 1.3 cm/μmol for the bands at 2178–2185, 2190–2204 and 2240 cm−1, respectively [24]. Concentration of sites with absorption band at 2240 cm−1 was determined at CO pressure of 1 Torr. Concentration of other adsorption sites were evaluated at CO pressure of 10 Torr. Lewis acidity of aluminas was also characterized by FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine. The powder samples were pressed into self-supporting wafers with a surface density of 0.014–0.016 g/cm2. The discs were mounted in a quartz IR cell equipped with CaF2 windows and a vacuum system. Prior to adsorption, the samples were pretreated in situ at 400 °C for 1 h under evacuation then cooled to 350 and 150 °C and the spectra of blank samples were recorded. Pyridine adsorption was carried out at 100 °C. The physically adsorbed pyridine was removed by evacuating for 1 h. The IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine were recorded on a FT-801 (Sigma, Russia) IR-Fourier spectrometer after the sample was evacuated in a vacuum at temperatures of 150 and 350 °C. The amount of Lewis acid sites was estimated based on the area of the corresponding signal in the IR spectra in the range of 1400–1600 cm−1 using the integrated molar absorption coefficients reported by Hughes and White [36]. Raman spectra were collected using a LabRAM HR Evolution (Horiba) spectrometer with a CCD Symphony (JobinYvon) detector that provided 2048 pixels along the abscissa with the excitation by the 514 nm line of the Ar+-ion laser. The spectra are measured in the 180° backscattering collection geometry with a Raman microscope at room temperature in air. Spectral resolution was around 2 cm−1. The diameter of the laser spot on the sample surface was about 20 μm (defocused laser beam) in order to prevent laser-induced destruction of the sample [37]. Morphology of the CrOx species in the catalysts was studied by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) using a ThemisZ electron microscope (Thermo Fisher Scientific) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV and a maximum lattice resolution of 0.07 nm. The device is equipped with a SuperX energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX) (Thermo Fisher Scientific) with a semiconductor Si detector with an energy resolution of 128 eV. For electron microscopy studies, sample particles were deposited on perforated carbon substrates attached to aluminum grids using the ultrasonic dispersant UZD-1UCH2. Images were recorded using a Ceta 16 CCD sensor (Thermo Fisher Scientific). 2.3 Catalytic measurements Testing of the catalysts in isobutane dehydrogenation at 570°C was carried out in a fixed bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. Reactor is a quartz tube (inner diameter of 14 mm) with a coaxially located quartz thermocouple pocket (outer diameter 6 mm). A 0.300 g batch of catalyst with particle size of 0.25–0.5 mm was used for each run. The reactor was heated to 570 °C for about 1 h in air stream (300 ml/min) and calcined for another hour in order to withdraw any adventitious carbon. Catalyst bed was purged with nitrogen (200 ml/min) for 10 min before the reaction. Two testing protocols were applied for dehydrogenation activity evaluation. In order to compare coking ability of the catalysts, a 20% mixture of isobutane in nitrogen (100 ml/min) was purged through the bed at 570 °C for 100 min. Subsequent cooling the reactor was performed while flowing the feed. It was necessary about 0.5 h to cool the reactor down to ca. 450 °C. The coked catalysts were withdrawn from the reactor at room temperature in air and were studied by physicochemical methods. Each catalyst testing without regeneration was conducted two times. The average values for activity parameters are presented in this work. Catalyst stability was studied in a dehydrogenation-regeneration cycling mode with a total of 50 cycles. A 20% mixture of isobutane in nitrogen (100 ml/min) was used as a feed at the dehydrogenation stage (20 min) of the catalytic cycle. The regeneration was conducted by passing air (100 ml/min) through the bed for 20 min. Nitrogen purging (200 ml/min, 5 min) was carried out between dehydrogenation and regeneration stages. Spent catalysts were also studied for comparison with fresh ones. The gas mixture was taken to determine its composition in the course of the dehydrogenation stage with gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector. GC analysis allows determining the content of methane, ethane, ethene, propane, propene, n-butane, isobutane, isobutene, linear butenes and butadiene-1,3. GC results were used for activity parameter calculations. Conversion of isobutane (X, mol.%), selectivity to isobutene (S, mol.%) and isobutene yield (Y, mol.%) were calculated with the use of Eq. (2), Eq. (3) and Eq. (4), respectively: (2) X = [ F C 4 H 10 ] i n l e t − [ F C 4 H 10 ] o u t l e t [ F C 4 H 10 ] i n l e t · 100 % ; (3) S = [ F C 4 H 8 ] o u t l e t [ F C 4 H 10 ] i n l e t − [ F C 4 H 10 ] o u t l e t · 100 % ; (4) Y = [ F C 4 H 8 ] o u t l e t [ F C 4 H 10 ] i n l e t · 100 % , where FC4H10 and FC4H8 stand for the molar flow rate of isobutane and isobutene, correspondingly. Amount of the coke accumulated (C, mgcarbon/gcatalyst) in the course of cycling testing was determined by Eq. (5) using CO and CO2 volumes released on regeneration stage and measured in situ with IR CO/CO2 gas analyzer: (5) C = V ( C O ) + V ( C O 2 ) 22.4 · m · 12 · 1000 , where m –mass of the catalyst (g), V(CO) and V(CO2) – volumes (dm3) of СО and СО2, respectively, released upon regeneration. 3 Results 3.1 Physicochemical properties of aluminas 3.1.1 Textural properties and phase composition Three calcination protocols for bayerite made it possible to obtain three aluminas with identical texture (Figs. 2 S and 3 S). Surface areas, pore sizes and pore volumes are equal for all the supports (within the experimental error, Table 1 ). X-ray diffraction patterns correspond to η-Al2O3 with signs of start of η-Al2O3 → θ-Al2O3 transition for η-Al2O3-800 (Fig. 1S). η-Al2O3-600, η-Al2O3-700 and η-Al2O3-800 possess the same lattice parameters (within the experimental error) and CSD size (Table 1). Thus, very similar supports were synthesized at different calcination temperatures in air-steam mixtures. 3.1.2 Surface hydroxyl groups of supports Surface properties of the supports were evaluated by infrared spectroscopy. IR spectra of the supports in the OH-region (Fig. 1) present vibration bands at ca. 3792, 3770, 3753, 3730, 3703–3680 and 3580 cm−1, which are typical for IR spectra of surface OH groups of η-Al2O3 [24,38,39]. Assignment of the OH spectra of transition aluminas is controversial. Several models exist which assign the type of OH group coordination with specific infrared absorption bands [38,40–42]. Some common points of view are as follows. The band at 3790–3800 cm−1 is assigned with OH group on tetrahedral aluminum ion. The band at 3770 cm-1 is either due to OH bonded to a pentacoordinated Al3+, or is located near a vacancy site, or in a particularly exposed positions like corners and edges. The bands at 3753 and 3730 cm−1 are thought to be related with terminal or bi-bridged OH groups bonded to one or two octahedral Al3+ ions. Strongly overlapped bands at 3703–3680 cm−1 are also due to different bridging OH species. Very broad band at ca. 3580 cm−1 is related with H-bonded hydroxyl groups [38,41–43]. Three aluminas under study have several differences in intensities of some absorption bands. Increase in calcination temperature of alumina from 600 to 800 °C leads to growth in intensity of the band at 3792 cm−1 with concomitant decrease in intensity of the band at 3730 cm−1. It may be inferred that the ratio between tetrahedral and octahedral aluminum ions increases with calcination temperature. This rearrangement of Al ions possibly is also the reason of changes in relative intensities of strongly overlapping bands in the range 3703–3680 cm−1. Enlargement of the ratio between tetrahedral and octahedral aluminum ions reflects the ordering of cations in the bulk of η-Al2O3 in the course of its thermal transformation into θ-Al2O3 [44,45]. Absorption at 3770 cm−1 in IR spectra is strongly reduced with calcination temperature of support. It implies that some surface reconstruction occurs which leads to disappearance of the most reactive OH groups of the surface [38,41,43]. Thus, the bulk of η-Al2O3 becomes more ordered while its surface to be somewhat less reactive. Overall intensity of the OH stretching bands decreases with calcination temperature of alumina. On this basis it could be speculated that hydroxyls coverage of the alumina surface lessens in the series of supports from η-Al2O3-600 to η-Al2O3-800. 3.1.3 Lewis acidity of supports Assessment of Lewis acidity of the supports under study was accomplished by IR spectroscopy of adsorbed carbon monoxide and pyridine. Spectra of the low temperature adsorbed carbon monoxide at 0.1 Torr are given in Fig. 2a. Absorption band at ca. 2240 cm−1 corresponds to strong Lewis acid sites (LAS) while lower frequency adspecies at 2204 and 2185 cm−1 relate to two families of weak LAS. The bands at 2204 and 2185 cm−1 most likely correspond to coordinatively unsaturated Al ions on regular crystal planes [43,46–48]. Band at ca. 2240 cm−1 characterizes complexes of CO with highly exposed Al ions which are in crystallographically defective configurations [41,43,48]. Intensity of the latter band is relatable to the intensity exhibited by the OH groups absorbing at ca. 3770 cm−1 [41]. The band with wavenumbers in the range 2155–2163 cm−1 is assigned to CO molecules hydrogen-bonded to surface Al-OH groups. Absorption band at 2204 cm−1 is the most intense at 0.1 Torr of CO. Fig. 2a shows that the intensity of the band at ca. 2240 cm−1 related with strong LAS decreases on going from η-Al2O3-600 to η-Al2O3-800. This is in line with the conclusion that surface becomes more inert upon increase of alumina calcination temperature. About 100-fold increase of the CO pressure strongly modifies the spectra (Fig. 2b). The bands at 2204 and 2185 cm−1 shift to 2190 and 2178 cm−1, respectively, and strongly grow in intensity. The observed red shift with the CO coverage is due adsorbate–adsorbate interactions [46,47]. Intensity of the band from CO complexes with strong LAS is about two order of magnitude lower than that of the former ones (Fig. 2b). Thus, there is a limited amount of highly exposed Al ions on the surface of aluminas under study. The supports differ in concentration of weak LAS (Table 2 ). Overall intensity of absorption bands at 2178 and 2190 cm−1 is the least for η-Al2O3-600 sample and grows on going to η-Al2O3-700 and η-Al2O3-800. Total density of LAS on η-Al2O3-700 and η-Al2O3-800 is very similar. However, weak Lewis acid sites with vibrations at 2178 cm−1 (Weak II type, Table 2), which have lower strength as compared to Weak I type, are more abundant in η-Al2O3-800. Thus, IR spectroscopy of adsorbed CO shows that with increase of calcination temperature the surface of η-Al2O3 samples with the same surface areas become more abundant by the weak LAS while strong LAS disappear. The infrared spectra of pyridine adsorbed in the range of 1400–1600 cm−1 at 150 °C is shown in Fig. 3. Three bands are seen in the spectra at 1449, 1492 and 1576 cm−1 which are assigned to 19b, 19a and 8b pyridine ring modes, respectively [49]. These bands relate to pyridine coordinately bonded to Lewis acid sites. There is no sign of a band at ca. 1540 cm−1 due to pyridinium ion indicating that aluminas exhibit no measurable Brønsted acidity. Band at 1449 cm−1 was used to estimate the concentration of Lewis acid sites. Table 3 shows the concentration of Lewis acid sites after pyridine desorption at 150 and 350 °C. The strength of the acid sites corresponds to the temperature of retained pyridine. Total density of LAS measured after desorption at 150 °C decreases from 0.23 to 0.16 sites per nm2 on going from η-Al2O3-600 to η-Al2O3-800. Thus, increase of η-Al2O3 calcination temperature reduces its Lewis acidity determined by pyridine adsorption. A reason for qualitative and quantitative differences of the total densities of LAS determined from IR spectra of adsorbed CO (Table 2) and pyridine (Table 3) could be steric hindrance effect rendered on pyridine. CO is rather small molecule and its adsorption is not hindered by steric interactions as it does for pyridine. Therefore, pyridine seems to chemisorb on the highly uncoordinated Al ions on η-Al2O3 [41,47]. Another possible reason may be the difference in alumina pretreatment temperature before the CO/pyridine adsorption. Aluminas under study differ in quantity of pyridine holded by LAS after its high temperature desorption. According to calculations, 45% of pyridine remain on the surface of η-Al2O3-600 after desorption at 350 °C but this quantity goes down to 26% for η-Al2O3-800. It may be concluded again that surface of η-Al2O3 becomes more chemically inert with calcination temperature since it loses the most reactive sites. 3.2 Characterization of fresh catalysts 3.2.1 Chemical analysis and textural properties Three alumina supports with the same texture and different surface functional groups were used to prepare three chromia/alumina catalysts. The catalysts prepared have the same content of total Cr and Cr6+ (within the experimental error, Table 4 ). The same is true for trivalent chromium Cr3+ content which is about the difference between the total Cr and Cr6+ concentration. Note that Cr5+ ions could exist on catalyst surface but their amount is at most 1–2% of the total Cr [18,50] and will not be discussed further. Surface areas of catalysts are equal (Table 5 ) and consisted with that of industrial chromia/alumina catalysts [25]. 3.2.2 X-ray diffraction and Raman spectroscopy CrOx-species were studied by X-ray diffraction. Fig. 4 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of the fresh catalysts. Beside alumina reflections, those from α-Cr2O3 (PDF# 00-038-1479) are seen. Structural parameters of the crystallized phases are presented in Table 6 . Analysis of the data obtained indicates a significant increase of alumina crystal lattice parameters on going from supports to respective catalysts (Tables 1 and 6). This may be due to the incorporation of Cr3+ ions into the crystal structure of alumina. The prerequisites for Cr3+ migration into alumina bulk are the similarity of ionic radii of octahedral Cr3+ and Al3+ ions (0.62 Å and 0.53 Å, respectively [50]) and high crystal field stabilization energies of octahedral Cr3+ complexes [51]. Crystal sizes of η-Al2O3 and α-Cr2O3 calculated using the Scherrer equation are very similar for three fresh catalysts. However, intensity ratios between chromia and alumina reflections reduces from CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 to CrOx/η-Al2O3-700 and CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 (Fig. 4S and Table 1S). Thus, CrOx/η-Al2O3-700 and CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 have higher amount of X-ray amorphous chromia and/or small Cr2O3 crystallites (ca. <3–4 nm size) than CrOx/η-Al2O3-600. Additional information about chromium structure was received by Raman spectroscopy. Raman spectroscopy has higher sensitivity to metal oxide crystallites as compared with X-ray diffraction [52]. Thus, the difference in crystallinity of Cr2O3 in the present catalysts might be further examined. Raman bands in the range from 700 to 1050 cm−1 (Fig. 5 ) are broad and strongly overlap. This pattern is characteristic for alumina-supported chromia systems. Spectra in the range of 750–1050 cm−1 are represented by bands centered at 871 and 1005 cm−1 together with wide shoulder at ca. 800 cm−1. All these bands point to the presence of chromate species [53–56]. Raman band at 1005 cm−1 arises from symmetric stretches in the Cr=O group within chromates while the 871 and 800 cm−1 bands reflect Cr−O−Cr stretches in dichromates and trichromates, respectively [55]. Relative intensity of the shoulder at 800 cm−1 grows in the Raman spectra from CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 to CrOx/η-Al2O3-700 and CrOx/η-Al2O3-800. It could be concluded that higher relative amount of trichromate species is on the surface of CrOx/η-Al2O3-700 and CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 as compared to CrOx/η-Al2O3-600. Four Raman bands present below ca. 700 cm−1 which are attributed to vibration modes of Cr2O3: 306 cm−1 (Eg), 348 cm−1 (Eg), 551 cm−1 (A1g) and 610 cm−1 (Eg). Also, broad and weak band can be identified at 395 cm−1 which relates to one-magnon scattering in Cr2O3 [57–60]. Fig. 5 shows that Cr2O3-related Raman bands are of nonequivalent intensities in the Raman spectra of fresh catalysts. The intensity of the band corresponded to A1g mode of Cr2O3 reduces on going from CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 to CrOx/η-Al2O3-800. It reflects the lowering in crystalline size of α-Cr2O3 and/or enlargement in content of X-ray amorphous Cr2O3 [61,62], in agreement with the XRD data. 3.2.3 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) Morphological features of chromium species were investigated by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis. According to EDX, large chromia crystallites are unevenly distributed over the catalysts and have predominantly plate-like morphology with dimensions from ca. 10 to about 100–200 nm (Fig. 5S). High-magnification TEM images depicted in Fig. 6 show that small CrOx particles also exist in the catalysts beside large α-Cr2O3 particles. The size of small CrOx particles is dependent upon the calcination temperature of η-Al2O3 support. CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 catalyst is abundant by CrOx species which are smaller than ca. 1 nm while CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 is populated by Cr2O3 crystallites of about 5 nm size. Cr2O3 crystallites were identified by observation of interplanar distances that correspond to (104) and (110) α-Cr2O3 planes. The HRTEM data (Fig. 6) are in qualitative agreement with the our previous results [24]. In the latter work, quantity of Cr2O3-like clusters in the CrOx/Al2O3 with ca. 4.4 at. Cr/nm2 was shown to increase with Al2O3 calcination temperature at the expense of isolated and poorly-interacting Cr3+ ions. Thus, XRD and Raman spectroscopic studies revealed that the increase of alumina calcination temperature enhances the content of X-ray amorphous chromia and/or small Cr2O3 crystallites (ca. <3–4 nm size) in respective CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts. On the other hand, HRTEM showed the reduction of the quantity of very small CrOx species (<1 nm) and increase of α-Cr2O3 crystallites of about 5 nm size. Combination of the results infers that increase of alumina calcination temperature promotes to form the Cr2O3 particles of about 1–5 nm size which are partially crystallized. 3.3 Dehydrogenation activity Activity of the catalysts was tested in isobutane dehydrogenation at 570 °C. At first, activity patterns were compared in the course of prolonged feed exposure without regeneration (Fig. 7 a). Small but well reproducible (Table 2S) difference in isobutene yield is seen between three catalysts. Differences in isobutene yields are related mostly with differences in isobutane conversion rather than isobutene selectivity. Isobutene selectivity is 95% at 10 min of the reaction and declines with time on stream down to 90% at 100 min for all the catalysts under study. Dehydrogenation activity reduces in the order CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 > CrOx/η-Al2O3-700 > CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 in the course of testing up to 40 min time on stream (TOS). However, activity order reverses after 70 min TOS. Consequently, CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 is the most stable catalyst against deactivation with TOS while CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 is the least stable one. Catalysts deactivate due to coke deposition forming principally from olefins [63,64]. For this reason, CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 accumulate more coke as compared to CrOx/η-Al2O3-700 and especially CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 (Table 4). This is also reflected by more pronounced SBET reduction after testing in the case of CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 (Table 5). Note that the CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts have comparable initial activity with the reference K-CrOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. K-CrOx/γ-Al2O3 deactivates by the coke to a lower extent (Fig. 7b) due to potassium dopant which poisons acid sites and inhibits side reactions [5,21,23]. As a result, isobutene selectivity for the reference catalyst is in the range of 96–97%. Distinction in the dehydrogenation activity of the CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts in the first 40 min TOS is caused by differences in quantity and quality of the active sites. Active sites for paraffin dehydrogenation are the most commonly assigned to be the coordinatively unsaturated Cr3+ ions (Cr3+ c.u.s.) possibly with adjacent O2− ions [4,8,10,13,14,65–68]. Four types of Cr3+ c.u.s. ions could be classified for CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts depending on their surroundings and ability to be oxidized into Cr6+/5+ [12]: • type 1: Cr3+c.u.s. ions generated from Cr6+/5+ upon reduction (redox Cr3+ c.u.s. ions); • type 2: non-redox Cr3+ c.u.s. ions in the isolated form and/or as constituents of very small Cr2O3 clusters; • type 3: non-redox Cr3+ c.u.s. ions on the surface of X-ray amorphous Cr2O3; • type 4: non-redox Cr3+ c.u.s. ions on the surface of α-Cr2O3. Recent estimation [12] for relative specific activities for these types of active sites showed that: i type 2 Cr3+ c.u.s. sites are about 4 times less active than type 1 sites (per m2 of Cr2O3). This qualitatively agrees with the results of other authors [13,14]; ii type 1 Cr3+ c.u.s. sites have almost the same specific isobutane dehydrogenation activity (in moles of converted isobutane/s per m2 of Cr2O3) as type 3 sites; iii type 4 Cr3+ c.u.s. sites are about 3 times more active than type 1 sites. This result contradicts the ordinary point of view about low dehydrogenation activity of α-Cr2O3 [22,27,69]. It is though reasonably to suppose that low activity of α-Cr2O3 is mostly related with its low surface area rather than with low specific activity of non-redox Cr3+ c.u.s. ions on its surface. Very probable that all three catalysts under study have about the same quantity of type 1 active sites because of identical Cr6+ concentration (Table 4). It could be inferred from the HRTEM, XRD and Raman spectroscopic results that the increase of alumina calcination temperature enlarges the amount of type 3 and type 4 active sites and reduce the quantity type 2 active sites. Indeed, partially crystallized Cr2O3 particles from about 1 to 5 nm size appeared in the catalysts are related to the type 3 and type 4 active sites. Correspondingly, very small CrOx species (<ca. 1 nm) are at least in part related to type 2 active sites (both the Cr6+ and Cr3+ ions could constitute these CrOx species). Thus, the increase of alumina calcination temperature reduces the amount of the least active sites of chromia/alumina dehydrogenation catalysts and increase the quantity of the most active and moderately active sites. Testing in a cycling dehydrogenation-regeneration mode with a 20 min dehydrogenation stage shows that dehydrogenation performance declines from CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 to CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 (Fig. 7b). Fig. 7b indicates that isobutene yields as well as coke amounts reduce with cycle number for the CrOx/η-Al2O3 samples as well as for the reference K-CrOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Three CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts loss about 10% of isobutene yield after 50 cycles. This loss of activity is caused by: • Moderate catalyst sintering (Table 5) which reduces the total amount of active sites because of chromium inclusion into alumina [13]; • Migration of Cr3+ ions into alumina as reflected by increase in lattice parameters of η-Al2O3 (Table 6). As a consequence, decrease in content and crystal size of α-Cr2O3 is observed according to XRD and Raman spectroscopic data (Figs. 4 and 5, Table 6); • Partial irreversible reduction of Cr6+ which are the precursors for the type 1 active sites. About 1/3 part of Cr6+ was irreversibly reduced in the course of testing according to results of temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) data (Fig. 6S). These processes are typical for chromia/alumina catalysts in the course of redox cycling [24,69,70]. Despite very close physicochemical properties of the spent catalysts, CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 remains to be more active than CrOx/η-Al2O3-700 and CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 even after 50 cycles. We can conclude on this basis that surface properties of alumina support still affect the catalysts performance even for chromia/alumina catalysts with high Cr loading (ca. 15 at. Cr/nm2) which is several times higher than a monolayer one (4–5 at. Cr/nm2 [52,69–71]). 4 Discussion Steam-assisted calcination of alumina supports at different temperatures in the range 600–800 °C made it possible to prepare a set of aluminas with identical textural characteristics. At the same time, surface functional groups are different for samples calcined at different temperatures. IR spectroscopic data indicate that the calcination temperature increase from 600 to 800 °C leads to dehydroxylation of the surface and to disappearance of strong Lewis acid sites. These changes are observed for alumina calcination in air [41,43]. In addition, X-ray diffraction analysis revealed the phase composition of aluminas under study conformed that of bayerite-derived aluminas calcined at 600–800 °C in air. Thus, applying air-steam mixtures instead of air in the course of η-Al2O3 calcination seems not to effect qualitatively on its bulk structure and surface chemistry. Rather, water steam seems to act simply as sintering promoter for alumina. Chromia/alumina catalysts synthesized from aluminas have the same surface areas and the content of Cr6+ and Cr3+. However, concentration of partially crystallized Cr2O3 particles from ca. 1 to about 5 nm size increases from CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 to CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 as was deduced from the XRD, HRTEM and Raman spectroscopic results. Further, amount of very small CrOx species (< ca. 1 nm) and large low-dispersed α-Cr2O3 particles (>5 nm) reduces with η-Al2O3 calcination temperature. On the other hand, concentration of weak LAS increases in the order η-Al2O3-600 < η-Al2O3-700 ≈ η-Al2O3-800 while quantity of OH-groups diminishes from η-Al2O3-600 to η-Al2O3-800. It implies that decreasing the coverage of alumina by OH-groups together with increasing the surface concentration of weak LAS promote to form the Cr species related to the type 3 (medium active) and type 4 (most active) sites in the respective chromia/alumina catalysts. On the contrary quantity of the type 2 (the least active) sites declines. This, in turn, leads to the growth of dehydrogenation activity. In our previous work [24], correlation was found between the total surface density of LAS on Al2O3 with isobutane dehydrogenation activity of corresponded chromia/alumina catalysts with 4.2-4.6 at. Cr/nm2. On this basis, it was proposed [24] that Lewis acid sites of alumina act as anchoring sites for Cr3+Ox species, and surface coverage by relatively large X-ray amorphous Cr2O3 clusters is promoted by LAS of alumina. At the same time, catalyst prepared from aluminas with very similar hydroxyl coverage had strongly different dehydrogenation activity. Thus, alumina's OH-groups were rejected as the main activity-determining functional groups. Present results for chromia/alumina catalysts with ca. 15 at. Cr/nm2 are qualitatively in line with the previous data [24]. Although the proposition in the work [24] is capable to account for positive effect of Lewis acid sites in alumina support on Cr2O3 clustering in CrOx/Al2O3, binding mechanism of Cr3+Ox species to LAS of alumina in the course of catalyst preparation remains unclear. Further, it does not reveal to what degree OH-groups of alumina participate in formation of catalyst structure. At the same time, it was well established that surface OH-groups of oxidic support governed the bonding and speciation of CrOx in the course of catalyst preparation [12,20,22,27,51,72–79]. Thus, there is a need of the model to bring together the obtained results and the literature data on the role of OH-groups on Cr-bonding. Let us deduce potential model of catalyst structure by step-by-step consideration of catalyst preparation stages: (a) Impregnation and drying. It is known that chromate ions electrostatically adsorb on protonated OH-groups [75,76] during the impregnation of alumina with aqueous solution of CrO3. After drying, chromium resides on the surface as chromates of different polymerization degree. Polymerization degree increases with Cr loading from mono- to polychromates and bulky CrO3 [37]. (b) Heating and calcination. Heating the impregnated catalysts up to >250 °C leads to etherification reaction between chromates and OH-groups of support [51,72,79]. The higher the content of OH-groups, the more Cr(VI) could be covalently bonded to alumina in the form of dispersed chromates like mono- and dichromates [80]. Consequently, polymerization degree of surface chromate species increases with consumption of OH-groups. Thermal stability of polymeric chromate species is small as compared to dispersed ones, and they decompose into X-ray amorphous and crystalline Cr2O3. [20,22,51,72–74] (Fig. 8 ). It was indeed observed by Raman spectroscopy that polymerization degree of surface chromates increased on going from CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 to CrOx/η-Al2O3-700 and CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 (Fig. 5). Further, very small CrOx species (< ca. 1 nm) are typical mostly for the CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 catalyst prepared from η-Al2O3-600 support with the highest hydroxyls coverage (Fig. 6). It is reasonable to expect a higher size/amount of α-Cr2O3 in the catalysts which was prepared from supports with reduced hydroxyls coverage. However it is not the case. Increase of alumina calcination temperature promotes the formation of the partially crystallized Cr2O3 particles of about 1-5 nm size at the expense of large α-Cr2O3 particles (> ca. 5 nm) and very small CrOx species (< ca. 1 nm). Apparent contradiction between the results and expectations could be resolved taking into account mobility of surface chromate species at high temperature. It is known that calcining the mixture of supported or bulk Cr2O3 with bare support like SiO2 and Al2O3 at ca. 400–900 °C in O2-containing atmosphere leads to oxidation of Cr2O3 into chromates with their migration onto bare oxide [70,81–83]. Mobility of chromate species over the surface is strongly dependent upon hydroxyl coverage of bare oxidic support. Higher dehydroxylation temperatures (i.e. lower OH group population) reduces chromate mobility [81–83]. Driving force for migration is the formation of thermodynamically favorable bonds with specific surface sites or stable compounds. Thus, equilibrium conditions is supposed to exist between supported Cr2O3 particles and chromates on the surrounding support surface [83]. Further, Cr2O3 particles of variable sizes seem to have different stability. Matsunaga reported that oxidizability of Cr2O3 reduces with Cr loading on alumina (i.e. with increase of Cr2O3 particle size) [84]. It could be expected that large Cr2O3 particles grow in size in expense of small ones in the course of catalyst calcination in order to minimize surface free energy. In other words, Ostwald ripening mechanism could be proposed for supported Cr2O3 particles. Accordingly, in the course of catalyst calcination, small Cr2O3 particles are oxidized by oxygen from air in the interface between chromia and alumina into chromate species. These chromates migrate onto chromia-free surface of Al2O3 provided that OH groups are available. At the same time, chromate species which are in intimate contact with large Cr2O3 particles decomposes into O2 and Cr3+Ox species thus increasing the size of large Cr2O3 particles. Experimental evidence of growing in size of Cr2O3 particles on calcination of CrOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at 600 °C was found by STEM in the work by Borisevich et. al. [31]. In the light of the above discussion, a model is proposed in Fig. 8 which revises the role of OH groups and Lewis acid sites of alumina in chromia/alumina catalysts. In the previous work [24] we assumed that alumina's LAS anchor Cr3+Ox, and OH groups of alumina do not affect significantly on resulting architecture of catalyst. However, it is more probable that both the OH groups and LAS of alumina are of importance. OH groups ensure chemical interaction of alumina with chromate species in the course of impregnation, drying and calcination. Simultaneously, alumina surface poor of OH groups (i.e. with high density of LAS) around Cr2O3 particles provides low chromate mobility over the surface and prevents growth in size of the Cr2O3 particles. As a consequence, key factors determining the Cr2O3 dispersion in chromia/alumina catalysts seem to be the ratio between densities of LAS and OH groups on alumina surface and their relative spatial distribution. The strength of LAS seems also to be important as long as strong LAS of alumina could be easily hydrated in the course of calcination and/or catalyst testing. Note that Fig. 8 is implemented to emphasize the role of the OH groups and LAS of Al2O3 and does not show the Cr3+ ions included into alumina bulk. Oxidizability of these Cr3+ ions is restricted and their participation in Cr oxidation and surface transfer is insignificant. The model presented in the Fig. 8 explains the differences in Cr speciation of the catalysts under study. Amount of Cr2O3 particles of about 1–5 nm size increases from CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 to CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 since the rate of Ostwald ripening for Cr2O3 surface particles in the course of catalyst calcination is low for CrOx/η-Al2O3-700 and especially for CrOx/η-Al2O3-800 as compared to CrOx/η-Al2O3-600. Disappearance of Cr2O3 particles of about 1–5 nm size during catalyst calcination is kinetically limited for catalysts with hydroxyl-deficient alumina supports. Relatively high surface Cr transfer in the case of CrOx/η-Al2O3-600 make the large α-Cr2O3 >5 nm to form possibly together with small Cr3+Ox species (<1 nm) being a residue from 1–5 nm sized Cr2O3 particles. The model proposed is also capable to accounts for the differences in catalyst stability against deactivation on dehydrogenation-regeneration cycling. Our previous work [24] showed that CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts (4.2–4.6 at. Cr/nm2) deactivated less efficiently after 20 dehydrogenation-regeneration cycles with increase of LAS density on parent alumina and its dehydroxylation. One of the reasons for this was the sintering of supported Cr2O3 in the catalysts which was facilitated at low ratios LAS: OH groups on alumina support [24]. The present model explains this result on the basis of the restricted ability of supported Cr2O3 to sinter when surrounding alumina is hydroxyls-deficient. For the catalysts under study, chromia sintering was not established as a reason of catalyst deactivation. In fact, all three CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts lose about 10% of initial isobutene yield after 50 dehydrogenation-regeneration cycles regardless of the ratio between LAS and OH groups on alumina. It seems that testing duration of 50 cycles is too low to reveal stability difference of catalysts with ca. 15 at. Cr/nm2 [12,27]. At last, given that CrOx/Al2O3 catalyst structure is determined by the ratio between LAS and OH groups as well as their spatial distribution on Al2O3 surface, dehydrogenation performance can be maximized by optimization of alumina preparation conditions. For example, by appropriate selecting of phase composition and morphology of aluminum hydroxide along with its calcination conditions, optimal distribution of Al2O3 crystal faces can be reached which have optimal densities of LAS and OH groups. 5 Conclusions The results of the present work indicate that alumina functional groups determine chromia dispersion in chromia/alumina catalysts with Cr loading of ca. 13 wt. % (ca. 15 at. Cr/nm2). Increase in the ratio between surface densities of weak Lewis acid sites (LAS) and OH groups on alumina diminishes the quantity of low-active large (>5 nm) α-Cr2O3 crystallites and very small CrOx species (<ca. 1 nm). At the same time, content of partially crystallized Cr2O3 particles from ca. 1 to about 5 nm size increases which strongly contribute to the catalyst performance. Thus, isobutane dehydrogenation activity of CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts is promoted by the increase in alumina calcination temperature. The results can be explained within the model which takes into account the well-known structure-determining role of OH groups of support in CrOx-based catalysts. According to this model, OH groups of alumina participate in Cr-bonding in the course of impregnation by solution of CrO3, drying and heating of the catalyst. When calcining the catalyst, thermally unstable polychromate species decomposes into Cr2O3 particles which differ in size and crystallinity. Supported Cr2O3 particles are not inert at temperature of ca. 400–900 °C in O2-containing atmosphere and are supposed to be enlarged by Ostwald ripening mechanism. Transfer of chromium (Fig. 8) is accompanied by (i) oxidation of small Cr2O3 particles into chromates with their migration onto hydroxylated surface of alumina; (ii) hydroxyl-mediated migration of chromates over alumina; (iii) reduction of chromates into Cr(III) on the large Cr2O3 particles. Thus, OH groups are supposed to facilitate Cr transfer on the catalyst surface while weak LAS of alumina, inversely, hinder the migration. Therefore, fine-tuned proportion is expedient between surface density of weak LAS and OH groups on alumina (together with their relative spatial distribution) to optimize the dispersion of chromia and dehydrogenation activity of supported chromia/alumina catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In this work, effect of alumina surface chemistry on physicochemical properties and isobutane dehydrogenation activity of CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts with ca. 13 wt. % Cr was investigated. For this purpose, three catalysts were synthesized from η-Al2O3 samples which have identical textural properties but different density of Lewis acid sites (LAS) and OH groups as revealed by IR spectroscopy of adsorbed CO and pyridine. Systematic investigation of CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts with a number of techniques (chemical analysis, N2 adsorption, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy) showed that (a) Cr6+ and Cr3+ quantities as well as surface areas are the same; (b) quantity of low-active large α-Cr2O3 (> ca. 5 nm) and very small CrOx species (< ca. 1 nm) diminishes while (c) content of partially crystallized Cr2O3 particles from ca. 1 to about 5 nm size increases with the LAS density on parent η-Al2O3 and its dehydroxylation. Correspondingly, isobutane dehydrogenation activity at low times on stream (up to 40 min at 570 °C) increases. This activity difference was observed in the course of 50 dehydrogenation-regeneration cycles. Therefore, alumina surface chemistry strongly affects the Cr2O3 dispersion and dehydrogenation performance of high-loaded chromia/alumina catalysts. On the basis of the results, a model of surface structure for CrOx/Al2O3 catalysts was proposed including surface migration of chromium being dependent upon LAS and OH groups of Al2O3.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of alumina surface chemistry on chromia dispersion and dehydrogenation activity of CrOx/η-Al2O3 catalysts with high Cr content
